STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 12, 2020
Trisha Sverns
Samaritas - West
207 East Fulton 4th Fl.
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-3210
RE: License #: CB410201266
Samaritas - West
207 East Fulton 4th Fl.
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-3210
Dear Ms. Sverns:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 10, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP)
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
322 E. Stockbridge Ave
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410201266
Licensee Name: Samaritas
Licensee Address: 8131 East Jefferson Avenue
Detroit, MI 48214-2691
Licensee Telephone #: (231) 777-5767
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Ann Meldrum, Designee
Name of Facility: Samaritas - West
Facility Address: 207 East Fulton 4th Fl.
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-3210
Facility Telephone #: (616) 356-1934
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1991
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
CONTRACT-FOSTER CARE
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 8/4/2020-8/7/2020

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(4) An agency shall maintain an orientation and training record
for staff members.
Three of twelve new employee files reviewed did not have documentation of the staff
completing orientation. This involved the orientation form being present but having
no record of them completing the required training on the form.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have the annual
reevaluation completed as required. This involved there being no description of the
smoke detectors working or being tested in the report.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Four of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have the Updated Service
Plan completed as required. This involved five Updated Service Plans (twenty-five
reviewed) completed past the due date 15, 3, 3, 1 and 1 days late respectively.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing Study Report with an
approved CAP on 10/31/2019, from the 2018 Renewal Licensing Study Report
with an approved CAP on 10/2/18 and from the 2017 Annual Licensing Study
Report with an approved CAP on 10/13/17.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated services
plan received since the last service plan from the child, the
child’s parents or legal guardian, foster parents, referring
agency, and others, unless the agency documents why any of
these entities cannot be involved.
4

One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the required
documentation in each service plan for the case file. This involved one USP missing
updated information in the placement section when the child had three replacements
during the period of the report.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing Study Report with an
approved CAP on 10/31/2019.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
One of seven open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the Updated Service Plan was completed within the required
time frame. Three USPs for this case file were completed after the time frame. This
involved 13, 11 and 7 days late respectively.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of seven Independent Living case files reviewed did not have documentation of
the Independent Living contract in the case file.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
MISEP 6.16 Page Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
23
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the supervisor
has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the
monthly meeting.
5

One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of the
supervisor meeting with the case worker each month. This involved one month out
of seventy-seven months reviewed, not having documentation of the required
meeting.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 – page
11-13
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport containing all items listed in MCL
722.954c.
For every placement/replacement the foster care provider must
be provided with the child's current medical passport at or prior
to placing the child.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the
requirements of the Medical Passport documented within the case file. This involved
the case file having a medical passport (dated 7/7/20) that was not completed and
had no information about the developmental concerns or medication given to the
youth.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing Study Report with an
approved CAP on 10/31/2019, from the 2018 Renewal Licensing Study Report
with an approved CAP on 10/2/18 and from the 2017 Annual Licensing Study
Report with an approved CAP on 10/13/17.
DHHS Policy Chronic Health Concerns
FOM 801 Page 9
Health care services for children with chronic health care needs,
such as children identified as medically fragile and/or within the
Children’s Special Health Care Services (CSHCS) program
require ongoing follow-up by the caseworker.
Caseworker Contact with Health Care Providers
For children with chronic, ongoing health conditions,
caseworkers must contact the child's health care provider as
recommended by the specific provider to solicit his/her view of
the child's medical status. Feedback from physicians and other
health care service professionals treating the child must be
obtained and incorporated in each service plan. The caseworker
must discuss the information provided by the health care
provider with the child's parents and foster care provider.
6

Contacts must be documented in the social work contacts and
the information obtained must be detailed in the medical, dental,
mental health section of the service plan. See FOM 722-6H,
Caseworker Contact with Treatment and Service Providers, for
more information.
All hospitalizations, emergency room, and urgent care visits
must be documented in the case service plan and medical
passport. The caseworker must obtain and review the hospital
discharge report. The information within the report is to be
discussed with the child's parents and foster care provider. File
the discharge report in the medical section of the case file.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation as
required about the chronic health concerns of the youth.
DHHS Policy Supervisory Approval - USP
FOM 722-09
Page 27
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have the supervisor’s
approval of the Updated Service Plan documented within the required 14-days of the
report date. This involved three of three USPs in this case file. The approval was 3,
1 and 1 day outside of the 14-day time frame respectively.
Two of seven open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the supervisor approved the service plan within 14-days. This
involved three service plans, 15, 13 and 3 days after the 14-day limit, respectively.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver, Parents and Youth over 14-Years Old
Page 2
The foster parent is required to sign each Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
Parents and Youth over 14-Years Old The parents and a child
over 14 are required to sign each Parent Agency Treatment
Plan
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
7

justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
Seven of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not meet the requirements
for the different signatures for the specific case file. This involved a review of
Twenty-five USP and Two ISP. Out of the reports reviewed, there were two missing
parental signatures, five late (beyond 30-days from approval) parental signatures,
five late (beyond 30-days from approval) caregiver signatures and seven signatures
(parent/caregiver) with no date.
Two of seven open Independent Living case files reviewed did not meet the
requirements for the signatures on the reports. This involved three USPs with
signatures that occurred beyond the 30-day time frame.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing Study Report with an
approved CAP on 10/31/2019 and from the 2018 Renewal Licensing Study
Report with an approved CAP on 10/2/18.
DHHS Policy CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH PARENT(S)/ GUARDIAN(S)
FOM 722-06H
Page 10
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the case worker had one contact each quarter at the parent’s place of residence.
DHHS Policy QUALITY VISITS
FOM 722-06H
Page 3
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A
quality visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
- Meets with each child individually without the presence of
other individuals to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions.
- Assesses each child’s needs and takes appropriate action or
offers services in response to the identified need of each child.
- Shows interest in the individual child to build trust and
establish rapport.
- Shares and explains the case plan in a developmentally
appropriate way while allowing the child to ask questions and
express viewpoints.
8

One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation in the
narrative of a quality home visits having occurred. This involved one of sixteen
documented home visits for this case file.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing Study Report with an
approved CAP on 10/31/2019 and from the 2018 Renewal Licensing Study
Report with an approved CAP on 10/2/18. Because of the continued positive
improvement with this from ninety-six percent to ninety-nine percent this year,
they can resubmit and continue to use their past CAP if they believe it will
continue to help with improved compliance.
DHHS Policy TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
FOM 722-06H p
15
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS within
five business days of the contact.
Seven of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
all of their social work contacts were entered into MiSACWIS within the required time
frame. This involved a review of ninety-eight home visit contacts by the case
managers. Of these social work contacts, seventy-four were entered appropriately
providing a sixty-seven percent compliance rate for this inspection.
Five of seven open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that all of the social work contacts were entered into MiSACWIS
within the required time frame. This involved a review of ninety-nine home visit
contacts by the case managers. Of these social work contacts, seventy-six were
entered appropriately providing a seventy-four percent compliance rate for this
inspection.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing Study Report with an
approved CAP on 10/31/2019 and from the 2018 Renewal Licensing Study
Report with an approved CAP on 10/2/18. Because of the continued high rate
of compliance (74% this year and last), they can resubmit and continue to use
their past CAP if they believe it will continue to help with improved
compliance.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings.
722-06B - page
2-6
The Family Team Meeting (FTM) is an essential component of
MiTEAM, Michigan’s Child Welfare Practice Model.
Type Time Frame
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 14 calendar days before the case plan due date.
9

Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanency Goal Review at Six Months in Care Within 30
calendar days from the date the child has been in care for six
months.
Six of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of
meeting all of the requirements for the Family Team Meeting. This involved three
missing FTMs in connection with the service plan and three FTMs that took place
after the end of the reporting period.
Two of seven open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation of meeting all of the requirements for the Family Team Meeting. This
involved one missing FTM and two FTMs occurring after the end of the report
period.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing Study Report with an
approved CAP on 10/31/2019, from the 2018 Renewal Licensing Study Report
with an approved CAP on 10/2/18, from the 2017 Annual Licensing Study
Report with an approved CAP on 10/13/17, from the 2016 Renewal Licensing
Study Report with an approved CAP on 10/5/16 and from the 2015 Annual
Licensing Study Report with an approved CAP on 1/21/16.
DHHS Policy FTM PRACTICE GUIDANCE
722-06B – Page
13
Discharge Planning in this item.
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:
• Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
checking it for accuracy, identifying areas needing follow-up,
and recording the outcome data.
• Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, to all
participants (in person and by phone), legal parents, and
casework supervisor. These documents must also be uploaded
into MISACWIS.
10

Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the DHHS-1105 was completed and uploaded into the MiSACWIS system. This
involved six missing DHHS-1105 from the case files.
Two of seven open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the DHHS-1105 was completed and uploaded into the
MiSACWIS system. This involved two missing DHHS-1105 from the case files.
FOM 722-09C FOSTER CARE ACTION SUMMARY REQUIREMENTS
Page 1-2
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
1. A replacement.
2. Termination from foster care placement.
3. A change in FC worker.
4. Agency change/transfer to another FC agency (if less than 30
days of completion of last case service plan).
5. A change in the parent's living situation.
6. Case closing (if less than 30 days of completion of last case
service plan).
7. Foster care transfer to adoption.
Two of eight closed foster care case files reviewed did not have the DHHS-69
completed in the required time frame. This involved both DHHS-69’s being
completed 20 and 24 days after the action to effect.
One of seven open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have the required
DHHS-69 documented in the case file. This involved three placement changes
without the required action summary.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Annual Licensing Study Report with an
approved CAP on 10/31/2019 and from the 2018 Renewal Licensing Study
Report with an approved CAP on 10/2/18.
DHHS Policy CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
FOM 722-6H PLACEMENT
Page 5
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child each calendar month. At least one contact each
calendar month must take place at the child’s placement
location. Each contact must include a private meeting between
the child and the caseworker.
One of seven open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the case worker had a face-to-face meeting with the child in the
child’s placement each month.
11

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 During this inspection, it was discovered that the labeling/coding of uploaded
documents was not as consistent as in the past. This lack of consistency
resulted in it being very difficult to always locate the document that was to be
reviewed. This issue was discussed with the agency and they agreed to take
action steps to bring back the level of consistency they have displayed in the
past.
 One of the CAPs for a licensing file special evaluation did not appear to
identify and take action quick enough for a foster parent that had told the
agency they were “burnt out”. This statement was documented in two other
reports, but the agency took little more action than trusting that the foster
parent would request respite help. The youth in care was presenting
significant behavioral issues. This was discussed and the agency’s licensing
supervisor agreed to begin evaluating this possible issue with each foster
home.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 The personnel files had all of the required documentation present, but the
files were difficult to work through. This was a result of the lack of separation
of different documents. It was suggested that the agency separate the
different documents within their specific location in the file.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The first incident involved Special Evaluation Report 2020C0628839. The
allegations involved the report that the foster father hit the youth’s head against a
window. It was also alleged that the foster father also grabs the youth’s face when
the youth is being disciplined. After an in-depth investigation, the family was found to
be in non-compliance with rule 9404 Behavior Management and rule 9201 Foster
parent qualifications. All aspects of the rules for a Special Evaluation were met
during the investigation. The corrective action plan involved a requirement that the
foster parents complete Trauma Sensitive Discipline training, complete an online
article for self-care, development of a self-care plan and make regular contact with
the licensing worker to verify compliance. The Licensing worker will also make
quarterly contact with the family to evaluate compliance with the plan.
12

The second incident involved Special Evaluation Report 2020C0628372. The
allegations involved the foster father grabbing the youth by the shirt and picking him
off the ground. It was also reported that the foster father waived his fist at the youth.
After an in-depth investigation, the family was found to be in non-compliance with
rule 9201 Foster parent qualifications and rule 9404 Behavior management. All
aspects of the rules for a Special Evaluation were met during the investigation. The
corrective action plan involved the foster parents attending a training on behavior
management and intervention at the Kent Coalition Spring conference. They are
also required to attend Trauma Informed Parenting, training on identifying
triggers/buttons for foster parents and learn how to respond appropriately.
Compliance is to be monitored during the monthly visits by the youth’s case
manager.
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan was in response to the 2019 Annual Licensing
Inspection Study.
The second corrective action plan was in response to Special Investigation
2020018001 dated 10/23/19. The allegations involved the agency failing to follow
policy/procedure when a youth goes AWOL from Independent living placement. The
agency was found in violation of DHHS-policy 722-03A Absent without legal
permission. The corrective action plan involved the agency holding an in-service
regarding the AWOL policy. The agency also developed a check list for AWOL youth
that is to be reviewed by all staff. The CAP was approved on 11/4/19.
The third corrective action plan was in response to Special Investigation
2020C0214008, dated 12/30/19. The allegations involved a youth entering care and
not receiving the appropriate dental care within the appropriate time frame. The
agency was found in violation of DHHS-FOM 801 Dental Examination schedule and
a corrective action plan was required. The CAP involved the agency’s support staff
tracking due dates for all initial youth and ongoing youth’s dental schedule. The
support staff are to follow up with the dental provider the day after a scheduled
appointment to ensure that treatment was received, and written documentation was
provided. The agency will also provide transportation if the foster parents are unable
to keep a scheduled appointment. The final aspect is that all foster care case
managers are to attend an Inservice training on the requirements for dental care of
youth. The CAP was approved on 1/6/20.
Staff Interviews:
Several different levels of staff were interviewed, and all provided similar statement.
They agency believes they are providing best practice to their clients in all situations.
The direct care staff feel very supported by the supervisors and administrators and
all report that the agency has followed the State guidelines for the situation with
13

COVID-19. Line staff believe the agency has provide the appropriate PPEs so they
can continue providing services to clients.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts or concerns during this period under review. The field
analyst interviewed/visited nine families, and all indicated being very satisfied with
the services being provided by the agency.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the
facility will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
8/12/2020
________________________________________
Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 12, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
14
